title: Who was richer: a merchant or a nobleman during medieval Europe? - Quora

response.answer_text: Who was richer: a merchant or a nobleman during medieval Europe? It depended on the merchant and the nobleman in question. A merchant had disadvantages. He wasn’t guaranteed anything; his ships could sink, he could lose his shop-front if he couldn’t pay his rent, he could lose his entire livelihood and end up on the streets since there was no social safety net. He had really be a hard worker and have good instincts, with much less actual information available to base those instincts on than small-business owners do today. On top of it, he had to pay taxes on pretty much everything, every step of the way, and not necessarily to the royal family. A lot of times his taxes - for instances, fees for bringing wool into London - went to a specific nobleman, rather than to the “government”. Most of the “governments” - i.e., the royal families - in Europe were in debt, you see. They looked to their noblemen to finance their wars, and often “paid back” their debts by relinquishing the duties owed on certain ports, etc., to the nobleman’s family for a certain period of time (say, 20 years). So a nobleman’s disadvantages were that he had to maintain his household (however large it was) and properties, he had to care for his people, and he had to be prepared to do his duty to the royal family, which often could mean serving in the government either as an administrator or a knight, and spending significant amounts of time away from home (during which time he, of course, had a much harder time overseeing his properties). A nobleman’s money came mostly from the taxes and tithes paid to him by those living on his lands - so if he didn’t have much land, his expenses were low, but so was his income. If he had a lot of land, his income was much higher, but his expenses were significant. Additionally, the royal family frequently came demanding support for its latest endeavors. In the early medieval period, most of the time it was safe to assume that the local gentry held most of the economic power in the region, as well. By the end of the medieval period, though, in many areas this had changed, to the point where many rich merchants were able to buy noble titles for their sons and/or daughters (through marriage) by promising the noble family in question access to the merchant’s finances. If you really wanted to be sure your target had money, you needed to look to the larger churches in the cities. Most of them, and the bishops who ruled over them, were quite well-off.

Merchants typically generated larger amounts of wealth particularly in shipping. The spicetrade was profitable as was rum, mead, coffee, sugar, salt, and so on. Nobleman held titles and land but often were closet backers of merchants. Nobles were commodity limited and were only capable of taxing the productivity of feudal serfs to a certain degree. The socially unacceptable sale of alcohol was often secretly backed by nobles. The social evils of drink were applauded in Sunday sermons and became investments on monday. Profit without appearance of involvement was rampant from slave trading to taverns. Gambling to prostitution the social evils were condemned in word but embraced in deed.
